{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3329153,"name":"mjbergman92","username":"mjbergman92","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/mjbergman92/{size}/219086_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-10T17:35:32.584Z","cooked":"

Discourse, which is the forum app that runs CD, IMO serves as one of the if not the most critical hub to collaborate and solve problems together as a community, resolving issues for teams despite the limited funding or mentorship available to them.

Within minutes or hours, many (I don’t know the exact stat) pressing concerns often posted by disheartened and struggling members of the community are met with overwhelming support to solve their problem and grow.

If someone else has the same issue, they can search CD and find a thread on the topic of their problem. Even better, a solution has often been identified.

So the workflow often goes something like this, assuming for the intentions of this discussion, that there exists a thread with a topic relevant to the issue at hand:

  • Experience Issue
  • Search and Find Thread(s)
  • Score Through Each Thread
  • Try to Implement Solution

Now here’s where I’m going with this. How many times have you seen the post marked as the solution, but in reality, several of the posts give the fuller picture? In fact, over several similar threads, you finally derive the proper fuller solution?

My point is, many teams have their own documentation, much of which is public. I hope you see where I’m going with this. If we made an unofficial documentation library on GitHub or some other platform with an incredible indexing system behind the scenes, I think it would be invaluable.

What about having an unofficial section of WPILib docs?

These are thoughts to get other minds rolling. Let’s maximize how we use what we already have, so maybe, with a little AI, we might not need a separate site, maybe we could AI generate a response with the information from all the related threads.

I would love to be apart of the solution. FIRST has given me so much, and I enjoy being a mentor, but I figure it’s either move up in the organization as far as contribution or take a step back, so I’m trying to build some report and increase my involvement in a broader sphere and see how it goes.

mjbergman92:

What about having an unofficial section of WPILib docs?

Why does it need to be unofficial? The problem is that teams have a hard time knowing what to trust.

Have you contributed to WPILib docs? There are tons of issues related to things you are talking about that we would love to have in there!

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":6,"updated_at":"2024-03-10T18:08:06.026Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":129,"readers_count":128,"score":60.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":458142,"topic_slug":"collective-documentation","display_username":"Jason Daming","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://github.com/wpilibsuite/frc-docs/issues","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Issues · wpilibsuite/frc-docs · GitHub","clicks":15}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":18342,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"WPILib Developer (Documentation), CSA"},"post_url":"/t/collective-documentation/458142/2","custom_user_title":"WPILib Developer (Documentation), CSA","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3329191,"name":"mjbergman92","username":"mjbergman92","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/mjbergman92/{size}/219086_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-10T18:19:34.851Z","cooked":"

I have not contributed. Looking at the issues now, I don’t see anything right off the bat I feel qualified to fill in on. Pardon the ignorance and harsh opinion, but at a distance, getting involved with the WPILib libraries seems like a huge learning curve, while the docs might be easier to begin with.

It takes time to build documentation, as you are quite aware as it consumes a decent chunk of your time, and for that we are thankful. To alleviate some of that, I think introducing an AI generated answer could really improve the experience on CD which uses Discourse. Do you see what I’m attempting to suggest?

I side tracked a bit with the unofficial section of WPILib docs. My focus was more on finding a way to index and concatenate an answer without having to manually write documentation OR to generate documentation using AI and making modifications as needed.

I also think that if this “plugin” does not already exist for Discourse, this could also be a lucrative venture if anyone is interested, considering Discourse is GPL licensed, but I believe modifications might be able to be added and sold, but I’m not certain of any of that. I just know there’s a lot of businesses and organizations that use Discourse and have lots of threads that would be nice to get a succinct answer from the collective knowledge within them.

EDIT: Looks like Discourse AI already exists and it can summarize discussions as well as help compose posts so people like me actually sound informed.

mjbergman92:

Pardon the ignorance and harsh opinion, but at a distance, getting involved with the WPILib libraries seems like a huge learning curve

Can you talk about what specifically gives you that opinion, as that is the opposite of what we are going for?

I am not saying it is “easy”. I think one thing people fear is some of the formatting? If you have good content (in a lot of cases you could get the info from CD) we are more than happy to help get it to fit the style

I believe we can use AI more, but it isn’t a “simple solution”. I am constantly worried about the accuracy. The documents we write need to be correct and will need significant review.

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":6,"updated_at":"2024-03-10T18:49:20.868Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":3,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":80,"readers_count":79,"score":36.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":458142,"topic_slug":"collective-documentation","display_username":"Jason Daming","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":18342,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"WPILib Developer (Documentation), CSA"},"post_url":"/t/collective-documentation/458142/4","custom_user_title":"WPILib Developer (Documentation), CSA","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3329509,"name":"mjbergman92","username":"mjbergman92","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/mjbergman92/{size}/219086_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-11T01:49:27.530Z","cooked":"

I will try one with a “Good First Issue” tag. I will keep issues bookmarked and check in the coming weeks to see about beginning to contribute and see how it goes.

jdaming:

it isn’t a “simple solution”. I am constantly worried about the accuracy.

It is simple to initially implement, likely difficult to obtain reasonable results in some cases, but I happen to believe that with the current state of the technologies readily available and are open source for communities like ours (e.g. HuggingFace library), we could produce succinct answers for 70% of questions that are asked or posted about after the 3rd or 4th time. It can only be as bad as the information available in the threads readers find, and it could provide more benefit when the full answer is between 4 threads. I had to recently do this exact thing… It was not too bad, but still, 30-45 minutes of reading I could have saved potentially if a GPT or some other model had concatenated some info and let me try it quick. If it didn’t work, I could have came back and looked through the threads myself.
